job_title: Forensic Research Analyst in Fresno, CA

review_title: Once a great place to work!
pros: We used to have such community and employee comraderie. When Pres. John Welty was there we had events for the staff, starting at the Presidents House for a Welcome back to work. Ice Cream Social, different Holiday Events, SnowFest, Spring picnic, competitions between offices for various events.
cons: No pay increases unless you change jobs entirely. If you like your job and location good luck, you will have the same salary forever. Staff dwindled down to one per college office, can be lonely and you lose freedom to ever take time off as there is no office coverage. Work life balance very skewed. Students are hired to fill former staff positions - huge no-no from the union - ignored by the college. Students salaries are just a dollar below the staff who have been there for years. No room for advancement.

pros: Great university to work at
cons: Bureaucracy can be too much

review_title: Great place to work, but I wish it paid better.

review_title: Fresno State is located in a great community to work and live.
job_title: Director of Operations in Fresno, CA
pros: Good benefits, including retirement, heath, vacation days, paid holidays. Beautiful university campus with grass and trees - great for lunch time walks. Many professional and personal development opportunities offered to employees. Vibrant energy of students. Offer 1 day per week for remote work.
cons: Lower salaires compared to other large employers. All the red tape and politics of a large institution. Limitation on remote work to 1 day per week.

pros:
Potential to be a great place to work.
Incredibly rich history.
Historically rich collection. 
Diverse faculty and staff.
Pay and benefits are excellent.
cons:
Workplace culture is a the biggest challenge. 
When it comes to Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, Accessibility, and Social Justice, there has been much talk, but very little action. 
Problems with racism, sexism, ageism. 
Issues with integrity. ("Google Castro sexual harassment.")
Google "Madden and Fresno State Library."
Too many temporary librarians; not enough permanent, tenure-stream faculty librarians.

cons: no windows in the tutorial center. Pay and benefits are tied to union negotiations with the whole CSU system, so pay is below what tutors and staff would make in another school system.

review_title: Good place to work, but not challenging

pros: Fresno State is a great place to work with diversity and inclusivity!

pros: Very flexible hours and little micromanagement
cons: Work can sometimes get monotonous

review_title: I have been here forever and and seen many changes.
pros: I love helping students and seeing them grow. I enjoy the collegiality among some staff members. The insurance is great and the union stands behind you if you get caught up in layoffs. You have the option of becoming involved in activities that go on during campus hours.
cons:
I have worked here forever and I make the same amount of money that I made 10 years ago. If you are looking for raises you need to look at administration - one of the Vp's offices... etc. If you are in a college office, student affairs office, etc.. you are not going to get a raise. Staff haven't even gotten cost of living raises in over 5 years.  Fresno State is management heavy. There have been to many cutbacks in staff while the VP's add a new executive for this and executive of that.  

Repairs to the campus are key issues... the parking lots are tearing up my tires so that the repair shops think that I am taking my car off road... really?

review_title: Lack of resources and vision inhibit growth
pros: It is in close proximity to all the large ag businesses in the US.  There is lots of opportunity to collaborate with industry.  The benefits package is good.
cons: There is lack of infrastructure such as wet labs, a bank of vehicles with which to do outreach.  There is no vehicle to spend grant monies such as a Procard.  You have to write the grant, bring the money in, then put up your own credit to buy lab supplies etc then they reimburse you.  They do not know how to handle grant applications.  A lot of promises before you come on board, but cannot follow through.  There is not even a position in their system for a post-doc from which to pay a scholar.  Antiquated and almost formulaic retention and promotion system that does not take into account research and grant activity.

job_title: Administrative Support Coordinator I in Fresno, CA
pros:
great work environment, great people to work with, great organization, great structure

I enjoyed working here. I got to really grow. The staff are amazing! My specific team are like my family and I think it's why I've stayed as long as I did. Anyone would love this place. I think it's a great place to start.
cons:
Limited room for growth

I feel that there was no room for me to grow. Upper management team didn't care to see that as well. There was nothing else that I could had done here that would made me a happier worker. I felt myself easily bored with my duties, tasks and responsibilities. I wished things would had been different.

pros: Almost, free education.  They assist in covering tuition fees of about 99% for employees and 95% for dependents (only for State employees).  The retirement package of CalPERS and Health benefits are kick butt!  The environment is friendly.
cons: Could work long hours to complete projects.  Weekends are sometimes necessary.  Students on campus are nuisance at times, but can turn to friendly environment.   We definitely need to be compensated to the national average per position and duties.  The national average is 55K for Analyst, and we are below that.  = = = = = = = = = Wake Up Fresno State! = = = = = = = = =

review_title: No change for advancement.............unless your the correct gender, of course.
pros: Most of the people who work here, are passionate about their jobs and what they do. The managers just seem to be passionate about advancing themselves and their good "buddies".
cons: If you perform a credible job, they will either not promote you because they don't want to replace you, or fire you because you threaten the less talented.

pros: I loved working on campus; it was very convenient since I lived in the dorms, and it was a ten minute walk to the department office. The work schedule was really flexible; I could always take time off work if necessary.
cons: The pay was minimum wage, and that's probably the only con I can think of. Like everyone else, I would love to get paid more, but I think it was still a fair wage for the nature of the job since it was so laid back.

job_title: Student Video Assistant and Secretary Assistant in Clovis, CA
pros: You meet a lot of people who are connected to many more people. But this is the same no matter where you go.
cons: Fresno State is a great place to start out with connections but not a place to reside and try to enjoy working for a long time. The budget at Fresno State has a big factor in the way a lot of things are run and how certain departments operate. A majority of the time one individual is held to many tasks for we do not have the staff to compensate many different people or a large staff.

pros: Plenty of departments on campus that are very proactive and forward thinking and have strong leadership. A lot of great people sprinkled throughout the campus that have a major impact on the learning experience of students.
cons: A lot of politics and things can tend to get slowed up by the governmental machine that is public higher education. Those prof's that are tenured seem to "slow down" and focus more on research than day-to-day instruction. Makes life as a student hard.

pros: Flexible schedule, hands on experience, and the wonderful opportunity to connect with professors. It's amazing to see the processes behind the scenes.
cons: I have no downsides to report - there is nothing that I would improve about working there. It was a very enriching experience.

pros: People are generally nice, although many are poorly trained and have to ask many questions regarding essential job duties. Even supervisors give wrong information which is frustrating to other employees as well as students.
cons: Poorly trained staff and supervisors. Lots of erroneous information given , which creates more work for those who actually know how to perform their jobs.

pros: A very healthy environment to learn and explore technologies and various domains.
cons:
Less flexible for international student and comparatively fewer opportunities with other universities in general either to the domestic students or to the international students.

Need to encourage more scientific research.

Technological departments in the Fresno State has to help the students to meet the industry. I am a CS student, in every career fair hosted in Fresno State, I could barely see 2 CS companies attending.

review_title: Inadequate budetary support of employees and students
pros: simple working environment and easy course work for students, good library facilities and a good football program, easy to get a degree
cons: arbitrary administrative decisions at college and school level, lack of transparency, large class size, mostly mediocre instructors and administrators, too many administrators, too few course offerings

review_title: Great Experience, Grind for your Future
pros:
Great support.
Great way to express your teaching philosophy.
Chances are you'll get guidance for your future career in academia.
Faculty parking.
cons:
Pay does not cover tuition.
Mandatory classes in addition to teaching responsibilities. 
Academia is not the best place for a career in this job climate.

review_title: Lots of work for little compensation.
pros: Gaining experience. If you want to gain experience as a teacher then this is the right place for you. If you want to focus on your own work, then you will be wasting your time.
cons: no perks, promotions, or priority given to employee's who have been there longer. A lot of politics which have a great effect on employee, but of which cannot be helped.

review_title: Great Health Benefits with Poor Pay
pros: The health benefits are amazing along with the diverse campus community.
cons: Often understaffed with vacant positions taking a year or longer to fill. Low pay for the amount of work and responsibilities assigned to staff. Management not very supportive and difficult to move up.

job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Fresno, CA
pros:
Working as a graduate student at Fresno State University gave me the opportunity to learn and hone a variety of skills under the supervision of an immediate overseer. 
Some skills gained included editing, office and clerical work, and website editorial work.
The hours were also flexible depending on my class schedule.
cons: The position was a one-year contract that could not be repeated.

pros: Enjoyed great benefits as a lecturer with full time units. Nice campus.  Access to the beautiful library is a nice perk.
cons: Part time lecturers get no benefits. Pay is low for part time. Support from the Department you work for may be lacking.

pros: Fresno state has great health benefits, a lot of professional development. Working under President Castro is amazing which makes the workplace and the university so much better to work for. Great union representing support staff.
cons: Unfortunately, Fresno State has a very low pay range for support staff. It’s heavily structured with too much management and too little staff.

pros: The best part of the job is having holidays off. Fresno State is laid back and it is reputable job.
cons: The pay is low, especially for students. Many times it feels like the hard work does not always pay off
